data.value: Haar-like features have been successfully used for image classification and object detection . It has been used for real-time face detection algorithm proposed in .

When extracting those features in parallel, be aware that the choice of the backend (i.e. multiprocessing vs threading) will have an impact on the performance. The rule of thumb is as follows: use multiprocessing when extracting features for all possible ROI in an image; use threading when extracting the feature at specific location for a limited number of ROIs. Refer to the example
Integral image for which the features need to be computed.
Row-coordinate of top left corner of the detection window.
Column-coordinate of top left corner of the detection window.
The type of feature to consider:
'type-2-x': 2 rectangles varying along the x axis;
'type-2-y': 2 rectangles varying along the y axis;
'type-3-x': 3 rectangles varying along the x axis;
'type-3-y': 3 rectangles varying along the y axis;
'type-4': 4 rectangles varying along x and y axis.
By default all features are extracted.
, it should correspond to the feature type of each associated coordinate feature.

children.type_: str or list of str or None, optional

data.value: The array of coordinates to be extracted. This is useful when you want to recompute only a subset of features. In this case
needs to be an array containing the type of each feature, as returned by
. By default, all coordinates are computed.

children.type_: ndarray of list of tuples or None, optional

data.value: Resulting Haar-like features. Each value is equal to the subtraction of sums of the positive and negative rectangles. The data type depends of the data type of
Compute the Haar-like features for a region of interest (ROI) of an integral image.
You can compute the feature for some pre-computed coordinates.

link.data: # only select one feature over two

signature.value: haar_like_feature(int_image, r, c, width, height, feature_type=None, feature_coord=None)
